bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, April 18, 1923

div1.p: Barber discusses research on the seasonal incidence of malaria types.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, April 18, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C
Barber
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Box 231, Crowley, La. Apr. 18, 1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I thank you very much for your kind letter of
Apr. 15. I shall get together all the information I can
in regard to the seasonal incidence of malaria types and
see what the figures look like. Dr. Bass has promised me his records
and Dr. Henry Thibault his. Thibault's records go back to 1907
and ought to be of assistance in getting the curve for that region.
Mayne, who will collaborate on the paper, will get the Memphis records
and whatever he himself has done. I found Wenyon's explanation
of the change in parasite types in Jl, R.A.M.C. xxxvii, 264.
Oct. 1921. His explanation seems good, but if true why does the
proportion of S.T. run up as usual in years when total malaria
is much reduced? It was so in a drouthy and cinchonized year in
Mitchell County, Ga. and Thibault has a record of a year of lessened
malaria at Scott, when the proportion of S.T. went far above the average
as did the resistent quartan. I acknowledge that the alternate
theory (if there is are only two of them) is not without
difficulties. If the summer heat brings out latent S.T.
you ask the warm winds to blow tertian in spring and subtertian
in the summer, all with the same breath! The question can be solved, I
think, although we may not have the data sufficient to do it for
this part of the world. xxxxxxxxxxx If Stránaky (Mediz. Klinik, 1918,
xiv, 311) is correct in his figures, we have something to the point.
1700 cases infected 1916, fall of 1916 about 90% tropica.
Brought to malaria-free hospital May and following months, 1917.
In June, 1917, tropica 4.5% and tert. 95.4%. In NOv. tropica, 49.8%,
tert. 50.1%

I have looked up van Ezdorf's figures and we can get some data there.
I would not accept figures from doctors, some of which he quotes.
Percentage of quartan so high that you wonder whether the doctor saw
the parasites on the slide or on the temperature chart.

I shall be much interested in your notes on Chara. As I told you my
rather few observations in the field indicate that our species of Characeae
do not inhibit larvae much. We are looking for early spring Nitella now.
I wrote Dr. B.L. Robinson, Gray Herbarium, Cambridge, Mass. last fall about
species of Chara, and he referred me to Charles Budd Robinson's “Chareae
of North America” Bull. N.Y. Botan. Garden, iv pp 244-308. I shall try to get
this, but perhaps would save time by having any species identified at
some herbarium.

Kindly give my regards to Miss Carter. I would have called last winter,
but, as you told me in the library, Miss Carter was then absent from the city.
Yes, I knew Captain Butler in the P.I. and have seen him again in Washington.

All success to your History of Yellow Fever. This is certainly a
great undertaking for any man at any age.

You will remember my asking you about cinchona cultivation,
Christophers' and Harvey give an excellent summary of cinchona
production in Java. Ind. Jl, Med, Res, x, 1923, p, 768. It seems that the
plantations require high elevation (about 6,000) and prefer volcanic soil
with heavy rainfall. After a careful examination of the map of Florida
I conclude that these conditions are rarely round in the tropical U.S.!
